comments.commentBody:
Pro Oil & Gas, I am. The USA has to Eat and raise their Childern...... not all have, 'second homes'.

The Andes are correct and have their right in the USA to disagree. The bucallic life is to be desired: I live in Carmel Valley, CA. The California 'MONTEREY SHALE PLAY' doesnt extend to Carmel Valley. No OilJack Rigs for C/V. We would be, of also DURESS.

'What you have here.......' you might also consider, is what the American Indians, all the way to San Francisco - their angst is hard to sense from objective history books - felt as the as the 'Righteous Yankees' cut down their forests and invaded their home lands without remorse.

All I can say is that let's hope that they will do it right - in short: THE CIRCLE is ROUND- It doesn't bother them in Texas and Oklahoma, of course........

Thanks Stan,
The strains of history recorded
Thanks, Stanley. Could you please send a copy of this blogpost to Gov. Cuomo so we don't have to throw him out on his ear?

While I originally recommended Knockatize' post because of his apparent geological knowledge today's magnitude 5.9 earthquake, while not nearly as catastrophic as the 9.0 Japanese earthquake would indicate that a much larger earthquake on the East Coast is plausible. While, this does not change his overall assessment that the damage inflicted by the earthquake will be catastophic it does bring into focus the possibility of a large earthquake on the East Coast.
However, even with that, nothing humans do can ever be done with complete certainty about future consequences.

We are filmmakers in PA and have been documenting some of the affects of the Fracking business on the local community, and the growing local opposition to Hydraulic Fracturing. The heavy truck traffic is one aspect of this story and thousands of well are projected in the Marcellus Shale region, so the impact will be long term.

Here is a link that we've shot about the traffic, which we call Heavy Fraffic.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KZZQxe6FiGA

Solutions to problems do exist, but are hidden from the public eye by an, at best, inefficient government and by profit-hungry, nineteenth century oil businesses. Check out http://www.bloomenergy.com to see one application of a way to address energy independence.

Prof. Fish, the English professor, may be interested in a linguistic sidebar to this issue.  Those in the industry generally choose to spell the practice "fracing" and contend that those who spell it "fracking" reveal themselves to be anti-industry hard-core environmentalists of the most dangerous sort.  English orthography and English pronunciation do not go reliably hand in hand of course, but one suspects that most English speakers, when presented for the first time with the word "fracing" would reasonably believe it would rhyme with "racing."  Opposition to "fracking" may have to do with discomfort with any word combining the dangerous combination of "f" and "c" and "k".

I wonder how Prof. Fish would write this article if the meeting he describes and admires, was about
a hypothethical gold mine? Extract gold or not extract gold, that would be the question. Seeing
what is happening to the price of gold, I for one, can tell you that the towns people would give it
a wholehearted aye and proceed to extract the gold. Natural gas, on the other hand, is quite cheap. and most folks would rather rely on windmills for energy, what is more, windmills make
people feel virtuous while hydraulic fracturing is an unknown entity after all.
Mr. Fish also opposes windmills in his bucolic upstate village. See http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/08/26/blowin-in-the-wind/

Thanks Mr. Fish. Towns across Upstate NY are moving on this issue.  State and Federal governments have been bought and co-opted and the wider population only sees the feel-good lies that Exxon and the rest of the industry are saturating the media with. If local townships move to ban it. They have no right to bring it here and we will send our local police to shut them down it they try. I own 100 acres in the Finger Lakes region and only a small fraction of landowners are in favor of this. Many farmers were tricked into signing leases by land men from Chesapeake who were disingenuous to say the least.. Indeed, I know of 2 people who had their signatures forged..

"Were a corresponding percentage of New Yorkers to turn up at a public hearing, there would be no place large enough to hold the more than 800,000 attendees."

I thought they were"New Yorkers"?
How is that Cape Wind project going these days?

Banning dangerous and seductive mineral production IS a form of regulation.

The big problems are well-casing leakage (what happened offshore Louisiana to BP) due to cost-cutting, which can't be remedied. There's no way to enforce the rules at the well site.

The other big problem is earthquakes, from lubrication of stress fractures by high pressure liquid injection, the very definition of fracking.

I haven't heard anything yet to suggest that fracking is safe and won't contaminate ground water through a leaking drill pipe or whatever.   As was shown by the recent  Deepwater Horizon disaster, oil companies often sacrifice safety by cutting costs.

We've been fracking for gas for about a decade in Texas.  It has done wonders for the economy and there are no credible or serious reports of problems.   There are gas wells everywhere in north Texas and our water is fine, thank you very much!  New Yorkers are crazy if they pass this up.

I imagine Mr. Fish is against the nuclear plant the provides electricity to New York State and probably is a big supporter of limited carbon dioxide emissions from coal plants. However, I also bet Mr. Fish is a regular user of electricity. He probably believes it is generated in the wall socket.

People like him are reminder that you can be educated and well spoken without actually being intelligent.

The citizens of Andes are correct for opposing fracking but probably for the wrong reason. The sooner we understand that the problem is the consumption of carbon in all it's combustible forms and that we need to switch to a non-carbon based energy system, the sooner we will retard the global climate disruption that in coming at us. Whether it is hydrogen based, solar votltaic, solar thermal, wind, tidal, or falling water it doesn't matter so long as carbon dioxide is not the biproduct.

The thing to keep in perspective is that we're all subject to some sort of cost/benefit trade-off with technology. For example, I would wager that there are a greater number of people at risk of dying in a plane crash or in an auto accident than from the effects of hydrofracking and yet we keep flying and driving virtually unabated. Yea of course we try to make these activities as safe as possible but we don't stop them completely. I'm sure that most of the folks in the effected areas would trade the prosperity that would accompany hydrofracking for the risk just as we risk the drive or flight in exchange for the convenience it gives us every day.

I was sad to read Fish's column -- it clearly showed how our political system is out of control.  We should be encouraging the responsible production and use of natural gas -- its far less of a greenhouse gas producer than oil or coal. We should also be encouraging our society to greatly reduce our energy footprint -- conservation is a win-win game in terms of foreign debt and global warming effects. Instead, villages dig in to say 'no', because they fear the government can't regulate sensibly (when impartial regulation is what government is really supposed to do well) and they know their politicians are pawns of the big-energy lobby, or any special interest lobby with money to give, in fact. And Fish thinks this is enlightened reasoning?  Where is our energy supposed to come from? Saudi Arabia? Big Coal? Now the environmental movement is fear-mongering against big Gas proselytizing, and the poorly informed public needs to make gut-reaction calls in town-hall meetings, instead of having a trustworthy EPA that regulates the energy industry -- well. Shame on us, and shame on Fish for thinking this NIMBYism is the right response, too.

Everything around us is either made from oil byproducts, made with energy from oil, or brought to us on roads (made with oil) by trucks using oil. If all petroleum energy production is redirected *right now* to do nothing but make windmills and solar panels, we still wouldn't have enough capacity to feed the population of 2050 by the time the oil and gas runs out a little father down the road. All of agribusiness as we currently know it is almost 100% dependent on petroleum. Everything we eat is imbued with an oil footprint, including the tomatoes in your garden. Without the efficiencies of the caloric density of oil, the acreage of our planet can support 2 billion people, at a stretch. What if we hit 11 billion when the wells run dry? Fracking or no fracking, we better have access to fresh water when we're back to hauling it with oxen. Not to spoil your day...

Good for Andes, New York for lining up and giving the energy bigs the boot. Gas frakking is a racket, anyway ..

Good for Stanley Fish for reporting this straight up rather than giving the usual, pro- energy company, pro- automobile spin that accompanies other energy stories.

Good for the Times for publishing the story without adding a bunch of pro- business propaganda designed to give the story 'balance'.

There is hope, that the industrialized 'futurama' of waste spaces, dirt, toxic dumps and pollution can be thrown off.
what a beautiful and sensible -- and heartfelt essay!

Ask the people of RIngwood, NJ about the benefits of having employment at the former Ford plant vs. the toxic mess Ford was allowed to leave behind and that is now killing the town's residents and its property values. Then decide if the folks of Andes called it correctly - short-term gain vs. long-term misery.

http://www.torquenews.com/1063/epa-nj-weigh-whether-ford-must-clean-toxi...

The problem is not with the fracking,the fault is with ourselves.It isevidenced by the example"at 2oclock in the morningwhen there is no evidence of a police officerand one is at an intersection with a red light,
how many would ignore the light?THe joke in the navy in world war2 was that said navy reg ulations
were designed by geniouses to prevent dullards like us sailors from killing ourselves. whether it is laziness,plain stupidity,or lust for gain,these characteristics,make a new development hazardess.
If on the other hand we ignore this new source of seemingly limitless energy we will be a society,frozen
in time. the choice is not easy!!!

Either there is a boundless supply of fossil fuels, or there is not. If there is a boundless supply, we should be able to satisfy our desires for energy with the existing sources. If there is not, then we should be concentrating our efforts on doing without them.

As a scientist who used to do environmental permitting work, I don't trust it one bit.

NIMBY is one thing, but NIMBY when the technology has already polluted many many acres and bodies of water in other places is another.

The fracking planned for NY state will affect the NYC watershed. There goes a city of 8 million.
